comments.commentBody: Another quick but challenging solve. Didn't figure out the theme though. Still was fun.

I fell for the SOFTC but never again. Otherwise it was a pretty quick solve although I did it so fast I missed the theme. I did like AVON clue and MT SINAI and NUCLEI as answes. I'm in awe of someone who can think of words ending in I, especially since I just constructed my first puzzle. And real trouble with 52D, but my bad.

Sorry to drag in yesterday's puzzle here, but ...

The only problem area seemed to be the cross of VIGGO x GESSO. It turns out that Mr Mortensen has a bit of a following, which bailed out quite a few solvers.

But what about us others? A stage name is often deliberately spelled unusually, which makes it difficult to guess. But, we did have the cross!

However, I didn't see anyone put in a kind word for the answer to "painting surface." Can anyone offer some insight?

Thanks,

-- jpgaskell

And now we are in Afghanistan trying to ameliorate the rule of horror of tens of millions of Taliban-sympathising Pashtun.

A Himalayan mountain country with no infrastructure and no WMDs or Bin Laden.

The best chance for success for Iraq is many thousands of jobs. The best chance for those simple jobs is education for those many thousands of simple jobs. Maybe like this:

The most valuable technology I know of is the information for designing and manufacturing all things made from materials. If so, in the New World order, the economy of the nation and the world would grow faster by having a common language for product design, manufacturing, and maintenance.

Wow! A master thought is now upon us! That would be like global manufacturing all under One clear blue sky by all such People of the World. Who then could work with that One language to serve the common good of all Nations.

Such vocational education studies might then be introduced world- wide in high schools, colleges, and universities. Many of us do know the benefits of vertical integration, open markets, and free trade.

The New World order does have a United Nations for diplomacy. Why not a race to the top, for such education starting with Haiti, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Iraq. Hey New York Times, why not blog this idea.
Thank you for this.
Thank you, Mr. Glanz.
A quiet, thoughtful testament and tribute for which I want to express appreciation.
Our misadventure has been as misguided as was the British attempting to manage New York City from 1775 to 1782.

Am I the only one made a little uneasy by this article? Especially the picture of the author at the grave of his employee? It's all a bit unseemly isn't it, this parading of grief by a privileged Westerner in his chinos and sport jacket(I think) free to travel home or to his next assignment. If there was a little less about the author, particularly that photo that verges on the grotesque, and more about the people he worked with, it might have helped.

I am sorry that you lost the two friends and colleagues you remember here. There have been so many Iraqis who died in this war, it is beyond one person's ability to comprehend, But it is important for you to have acknowledged the premature and much-mourned deaths of these two men, Fakher Haider and Khalid Hassan. Thank you for this salute.

Hey, with a puff of mighty insight, I wrote this song quite some time ago: “They’re not gonna know how much they’ve lost until they’ve gotten what they’ve been wanting”. “See the cool clear water flow’ in down the hill to the muddy sea, well that’s …” Some have said it like this: Be careful of what you wish for because you might get it; a lot more of it then you really have been wanting; with a slightly expanded tag.

and what responsibility do you and the NYT accept for this man's death. He has contributed to the success of your career, to the material that filled the paper? I fear that you, The Times, and the US government which according to another article has been more than slow, more than incompetent, more than irresponsible in protecting those who aided them in their warring debacle and so casually signed a warrant of execution for those they had exploited.

It is a sorry world
Beautiful piece. Thank you for the courageous work and carrying out your job with such empathy and humanity.

Inna lillahi wa inna ilaihi raji'un. May Allah (SWT) have mercy on their souls and may He grant peace and understanding to those left behind.  As a human being this story brought me to tears.  As a Muslim this story embarrasses me - to know that we as Muslims treat our brothers and sisters in Islam this way.
I'm sorry, too.

While the oil is not flowing in greater volume in Iraq, the tears surely are. That's one lasting consequence of that invasion that Iraqis will not soon forget, even as we wave our flags and ask our god to shower blessings upon "our great country."

No one uses the word trespass anymore.   Yet it is everyone's common line in the sand that one should never cross intentionally.    It was our Creators first warning to us using his garden as the tool to get the point across.   He does not defend trespassers.   You can't hear anyone else when you talk, text or rock.   You hear God in the silence.  Since God is love, listen.  I saw an metal art work that said we uphold the fallen and we heal the sick, we uphold the fallen and we heal the sick, we uphold the fallen and we heal the sick.....   it was a long scroll repeating this many times.    It is the story of life and the road to Heaven.   I'm sure this author upheld many and healed many but my mom use to say that even Jesus, bound as a human, could not do it all.    Gratitude to the author for being there when he could, so we could be here holding on to some sense of safety for kids and ourselves.    War stops when falsehood stop.  May truth be you always.  It brightens the world.    The metal work was at the Jewish Hospital in Cincinnati.   I'm sorry I don't know the artist.   But the work says it all.   Shalom.

unbelievable sad. when we will ever learn that war is not a decent solution to any problem?

when will we ever learn?

Tilting at windmills is not the same as ending a war. Unlike the widow's calculus of pursuits, our work is done.
--Walter Rhett

Thank you for your words and stories. You have brought Iraq even closer to us and helped us to see the faces of the people a little more clearly. Salaam to you as you carry these stories and people with you.
The point being?

Mr. Glanz,

Thank you for writing this essay, for remembering your colleagues and for reminding us of the cost of War. You also remind us that there are so many unexpected consequences of our actions -- our War - in Iraq.

Life is so fragile, people, their motives are so inscrutable. Why would people who ostensibly have been living together for some decades, who belong to the same country, speak the same language, suddenly take it into their heads to kill on the basis of an abstract thing like a religious practice?

Sorry for your loss.

No one knew????

http://www.salon.com...

I surely don’t know any of the many other sides of that story. But I will venture that if I adequately knew, it’d be another sign that the divine kind law of causes and effects always will, will out; and if so, it would always be the best alternative for every one of us; all in all in due course.  The effects to consider will always be more than two.  Those most entrapping will always be those most hidden from us, in one way or another.
